div.p:
Iam nunc accedamus Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 1, n. 1 . After the Master determined about the visible mission of the Holy Spirit, now he makes a determination about the invisible mission. And this is divided into three parts. I say this because in the first he posits his intention about charity and delight, in the second place he shows how charity receives augmentation or intension, in the third place he brings up the opposite opinion with its support. The second begins at
hic quaeritur si caritas Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 17, c. 5 . The third at
supra dictum est quod Spiritus Sanctus Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 17, c. 6 .

The first part which is the principal part of the present lecture is divided into three parts because in the first place the Master asserts his opinion, in the second place he adds a conformation to his opinion, and in the third place he adds a response, some quibbling. The second starts at
ne autem in re tanta Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 17, c. 1 . The third at
sed ne forte Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 17, c. 3 .

Whether personal love of the divine essence is formal love of a created power? Whether the immense gift is the formal love by which the real one loving rightly loves the highest good? Whether the highest love of the Holy Spirit produced through two spirators is that by which we are formally lovers of the highest good, justice, and truth?

That this is not the case is argued in the first place because created charity with the will sufficiently produces some meritorious act, therefore positing that the Holy Spirit is formally that by which the mind loves and earns merit strays from the truth. The consequence is valid and the antecedent seems to come from the mind of the
Apostle in I Corinthians 15
who says,
I have worked harder than all of them, but not I, but the grace of God within me
I Corinthians 15:10 .

In the second place, only charity
divides among the sons of the kingdom and perdition
Augustine, De Trinitate, XV, 18, 32 (CCL 50A, 507) , as says Augustine XV De Trinitate, in chapter 18 . But this love is not the highest personal love or the Holy Spirit, as Our Gregory says is clear from the text of I Corinthians 13, where it says
if I speak with tongues of men and of angels
I Ad Corinthios 13:1
etc. Again Romans 5
the charity of God is diffused in your hearts
Romans 5:5

In the third place, nothing immeasurable is able to be the intrinsic form of something measured, therefore. The consequence is valid. The antecedent is proved because subjective inherence is repugnant to the unmeasured. In the second place because the measured then would have unmeasured justice formally, which is repugnant, therefore.

In opposition, it is argued that the highest love alone is able to sufficiently justify the created mind and to actuate for ordinate loving, therefore the question is true. The consequence is good, and the antecedent is clear because the Holy Spirit is able to be communicated to the created mind without incomplex created gifts,
as is proved above Vide supra .

First conclusion: that created love is a habit supernaturally infused to the mind by God actuating the mind in a special way, this making the mind beloved to God and God beloved to the mind from the divine acceptance actually or habitually since it is partially causing some merit of the mind. This is proven in the first place that the habit is supernaturally infused. This is clear from
Extra, de haereticis in clementinis Extra, XXX . In the second place, that it is from God actuating the mind etc., is clear because God is the life of the soul, therefore he actuates it in its spiritual being. The consequence is valid. The antecedent is from
Gregory Super Ezechialem,
in the second part of his fifth homily
Gregorius Magnus, Super Ezechialem . In the third place, that he makes the mind pleasing is clear through the word of Christ
I know my sheep John 10:27
or
I know whom I have chosen John 13:18 . Item, John 13
he loved them to the end John 13:1 . But that charity makes God beloved to the mind is clear though
Augustine in Moribus ecclesiae, in chapter 14
through love, he says, it happens that we formed to God
Augustine, Moribus Ecclesiae, c. 14 . Again
De doctrina christiana
he calls love the motion of the soul
Augustinus, De Doctrina Christiana, 3, 10 . Again in the book of the Confessions
my weight is my love by which
Augustinus, Confessionum, 13, 9, 10
etc. The fourth part is clear from the above.

The first corollary: it stands that charity actually informs the mind and the same mind does not actually incline, in opposition to the opinion of
Hugolino, in distinction 17 or 14 Hugolinus, XXX . It is clear that created charity does not incline unless moved by the Holy Spirit since this is its instrument and also according to itself. Whence he says that in meritorious work uncreated charity gives life, inclines, and operates, but the potency or will only operates, and the Holy Spirit does not actually move except when it wishes the mind to act, as is clear in
the first book of Ezekiel , where it says
where the impulse of the spirit was, that is where they went Ezekiel 1:12 .

Second corollary: the one having the habit of charity is not able to go out into its proper act unless the Holy Spirit actuates and moves the created will. This is clear through
Augustine, in his book, the sermon on the words of the lord, etc.
where he says that
the good which makes man good in nothing other than God, for one does restore a good man unless that person is always good
Augustinus, XXX , against the position of
Henry of Ghent Henry of Ghent, XXX .

Third corollary: love does not only produce merit with respect to some intension and grade, but also with respect to substance and act. This is clear from the last two parts of the conclusion which indeed with this corollary are proved by the saying of the Apostoli alleged above for the first argument
laboravi I Corinthians 15:10
etc.

Second conclusion: meritorious action of eternal life inasmuch as it is of this type proceeds formally and effectively from the grace of eternal predestination. This is proved because ratio of divine acceptance of any type of good operation corresponds to this kind of grace alone, therefore. In the second place, because this alone renders the mind worthy for eternal life, therefore. In the third place, it is proved through
Augustine, in his book De haeresibus, in chapter 8 Augustine, XXX , where he shows that through this alone is one able to fulfill the divine command, therefore.

First corollary: it is possible that an act is accepted by God and no infused habit is in the mind, against
Scotus, in this distinction 17, question 2 Scotus, I, d. 17, q. 2 , because only the grace of predestination is a means suitable for making a good act accepted by God and to be meritorious of eternal life as the conclusion states.

Second corollary: though every meritorious act is produced freely by a created will, nevertheless for something to be a meritorious act is not in the power of human beings alone because it is not in their power that such an act is accepted by God, therefore. This is confirmed because then the acts of the blessed would meritorious just as those of the pilgrim. The consequence is clear because every causality which the blessed had in this life with respect to a good act, they also have in heaven, they cause more perfectly, therefore this corollary is in opposition to Scotus where noted above.

The third corollary: it is not the case that some numbered among the damned had ever merited the prize of those being saved. This is clear because no act of foreknowledge proceeds from the grace of predestination, therefore no such thing is meritorious of eternal life. The consequences is clear from the conclusion from which it is able to be elicited that just as it is impossible that being saved is foreknown, so it is impossible that a life is foreknown to merit or have merited eternal life.

Third conclusion: personal love of the divine essence is a vital form of the created power elevating and actuating in some good doing. This is proved through the saying of the Apostle
love of God is diffuse Romanos 5:5
etc. which
Augustine Augustine, xxx
explains is about uncreated charity. Again, in Romans
For the spirit gives testimony to our spirit that we are sons of God
Romans 8:16 , and in the same place,
whoever are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God
Romans 8:14 , where the Apostle speaks notionally in the spirit and not through the Holy Spirit. For the third question there are the words of
Augustine XV De Trinitate, in chapter 5, de parvis
love which is from God and is God is properly the Holy Spirit
through which charity is diffused in our hearts through which total charity dwells in us
Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, c. 5 , and there he says more things related to what we have proposed.

The first corollary: something is the form of another thing elicitively or actuatively and to the same thing it is not in it constitutively, inhaesively, or informatively, against
Fastinus, in book 3, question 2
Fastinus de Asti, III, q. 2 . This is clear because that it is able to be communicated to itself intrinsically, representatively, exemplarily, immutatively, causally, and elevatively, supernaturally, just as
Lord Jacob of Viterbo deduces in his Quodlibetis
Iacobus de Viterbo, Qudodlibet, xxx .

The second corollary: the Holy Spirit or the highest personal love is the efficient formal ratio by which, through which, and on account of which the act of ordinate love is elicited, in opposition to
Gregory, in book 1, distinction 17, question 1, article 1, near the end Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 17, q. 1, a. 1, . This is clear because otherwise while the Holy Spirit is formally and intrinsically actuating it would be possible for the mind to be elevated to gratuitous being, which is false. This is confirmed because the Holy Spirit is personally intrinsic to the mind without its own gifts by such intimatione which would suffice for gratituous being. This is clear from what has been said, and just he himself also concedes in
in that distinction, article 2 XXX, I, d. 17, a. 2 . Again, if the Holy Spirit were given to the created mind without its own incomplex created gifts, it would not be otherwise united to it in this case than it is now, but in that the mind would love in the Holy Spirit, through the Holy Spirit, and on account of the Holy Spirit, therefore it loves just as now give that it loves ordinately. This is clear through
the same person, in book 1, distinction 14
XXX, I, d. 14

Third corollary: created love of the mind which is elevative into God is the same as the grace that gratifying the mind, against
Saint Thomas, first part of the second part, question 2, article 3
Thomas Aquinas, S.T., I-IIae, q. 2, a. 3 , and against
Thomas of Strasbourg, in distinction 17 of books 1, question 1, article 4
Thomas de Argentina, I, d. 17, q. 1, a. 4 . The corollary is clear because both the Apostle and Augustine indifferently exchange one for the other and use them to mean the same thing in diverse places. This is confirmed because otherwise it would be the case that the mind is acceptable to God but not beloved or vice versa, which does not seem to be possible.

From what has been said affirmative part of the title is clear, namely that personal love etc., for in the specified mode it is the form forming, causing, and supernaturally elevating the mind, nevertheless it is not the form inhering or composing.

div.head: Objections and responses
div.p: Against the first conclusion and the first corollary, created charity is the weight of the soul as is clear through what has been said, but weight always actually presses and weighs down that to which it is joined, therefore charity always actually moves and inclines the potency in which it is to acting well

In the second place against the second corollary, the one having the Holy Spirit does not lack the special motion of the Holy Spirit, but the one having charity has the Holy Spirit, therefore. The major is known. The minor is proved through
Apostle
who says
the grace of God or charity is diffuse
Romans 5:5
etc.

In the third place against the third corollary, if charity effected meritorious action with the will, either this happens later, and this is not the case according to
Anselm Monologion 5
Anselmus, Monologion, 5, xxx
where he compares the grace to a dwelling and the will to a mule, or prior, and this is not because then the habit would use the potency against the ratio of a habit because a potency ought to use a habit, or they equally would produce in the same moment, and this is not since they are partial causes and differ equivocally in species. Therefore charity in no way concurs effectively. The consequence is clear by this sufficient division

Against the second conclusion and its corollaries, it would follow that God would have another volition according to reason about some "oso" itself in no variated thing. The consequent is false, and the consequence is proved because a sinner before penitence is not worthy of eternal life, therefore he is not accepted for eternal life, and after penance he is worthy and accepted, therefore. And this is true either through something inhering, and if this is true, it would be had against the conclusion because it will be necessary to put a created form, or through nothing, and if this is true, the proved consequence would be had because while no change is made in the mind God with respect to his volition will have something different than before.

In the second place, if God were to accept penitence for eternal life, this would either be to will to beatify someone with a will pleasing at that time, and this is not the case because then he would immediately beatify, or it is to will this according to
disposition which he now has to be worthy for such a prize which he did not previously wish to be worthy of, but such diversity is not able to put in the divine will unless on account of the diversity of the creature or on account of some other mode of being of the creature.

In the third place, the divine volition, since it is one act in itself, does not have ratio of opposite actus or the ability to wish and not wish without a distinction of objects. Therefore, when God wishes to accept a sinner as justified for something to which he does not want, it follows that this distinction of the divine will necessarily requires an actual distinction on the part of the objects, therefore, otherwise the justified would be in a different way than the non justified and not unless through created grace, therefore.

Against the third conclusion, because this seems to be the
opinion of the Master in distinction 17 Lombard, I, d. 17, xxx , which ought not to be held because many inconveniences follows. For on this matter it follows that the act of love will not be meritorious, in the second place it will not be voluntary, in the third place it will not be delightful, in the fourth place that act is the Holy Spirit, in the fifth place that man would merit from his purly natural abilities, in the sixth place that the Holy Spirit in an act of delight would be united suppositionally to the rational nature, all of which are false.

Against the first corollary, because when the form is not more removed, the form for the thing that it informs, than the form is in its own nature, it follows that the Holy Spirit would be unmeasurable to the mind and would be an immeasurable form, and consequently immeasurable justice, and thus the well being of God and the of men will not be two different things, contra the
Blessed Augustine, De quaestionibus novi et veteris testamenti
Augustinus, De quaestionibus novi et veteris, xxx .

In the third place against the second corollary, it is able to be argued
from the words of Gregory where stated above Gregorius Ariminiensis, XXX
in the first place because the quia Apostle speaks uniformly about charity and the other habits.

In the second place, through
Blessed Augustine, homelia supra canonica Iohannis , explaining this passage from
Romans 8
the Spirit himself asks for us Romans 8:26
etc.,
what Augustine says
does
the Spirit himself intercedes for the saints Romans 8:27 , except the charity itself which is made in you through the Holy Spirit
Augustinus, XXX , therefore this love is not the Holy Spirit otherwise it would be said to be made, which is false.

Against the third corollary, the substance of charity and of grace are diverse, therefore they are distinct habits. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because
the immediate subject of grace is the substance of the soul, but the subject of created charity is the will
Thomas de Argentina, In Sent. II, d. 26-27, q. 1, a. 2 (Genoa 1585, 185v)
, therefore. This is the opinion of
argument of Thomas of Strasbourg .

div.head: Responsiones
div.p:
To the first, it is said that weight always inclines in act or in habit, and
Augustine
seems to have understood it in this way, saying
by that I am drawn wherever I am drawn
Augustinus, Confessions, XIII, 9, 10 . He does not say by that I am always drawn, nor is this similar to the weights of natural heavy things because charity is a supernatural weight which actually inclines only as much as the Holy Spirit wishes it to incline and to act.

To the second, in the major premise it is said that the Holy Spirit is able to be had as if gratificatively and habitually, nevertheless I do not say through the mode of habit and it is able to be had motively and actually. In the first mode, major is denied. In the second mode, the entire argument is conceded because I speak about this motion and habit in the conclusion.

To the third, in the first place it is said that, if such an act should be considered as an act, thus it is principally from God and as if equally first from grace and the will. If it were considered as free, thus it would be first from God, second from grace, and third from the will. If as meritorious, thus
Hugolinus
Hugolinus, XXX says that neither grace nor the will has effective latitude with respect to this. But
Scotus, in distinction 17 Scotus, I, d. 17 , says that is thus principally from God, second from grace, third from the will. But Scotus in the aforesaid response of Hugolinus
in book two regarding distinction 27 Scotus, II, d. 27
because regard this to be valid.

To the first against the second conclusion, I say that all three of these reasons are founded on something false, namely that the predestined person existing in mortal sin is not accepted by God and then afterwards is accepted, which I do not concede. Indeed, I say that the predestined one however much a sinner is always and was from eternity accepted by God for having eternal life. And the Subtle Doctor also says this
against which these corollary are posited, as is clear
in his second question against this distinction
Scotus, XXX , nevertheless
in this same distinction Scotus, XXX
he posits a triple acceptance. The first is the simple agreeableness in which God accecepts every possible thing or future. The second is the efficacy and this is that by which he wishes a thing to be in effect and in way necessarily required for it, and thus he accepts every existing thing. Third is a special acceptance which is a volition ordered to a vow, such that something greater is achieved and this is perfective. And this meaning about which is being spoken, but not about the others, as is clear from what has been said.

To the first against the third conclusion, it is said that according to the exposition according to which the opinion of the Master is commonly expressed this is false because my conclusion does not negate the created habit of charity nor does it posit that the Holy Spirit is love informatively inhering in the mind, but intrinsically and actuatively. But whether the Master denied the created habit, Scotus says, so also does Thomas of Strasbourg, that he does not, just as it is clear
in distinction 3 of the first book Scotus, XXX, I, d. 3; Thamas de Argentina, XXX, I, d. 3
and
distinction 26 of the second book Scotus XXX, II, d. 26; Thamas de Argentina, XXX, II, d. 26 . In the second place, I say that the inferred inconveniences do not follow from the sayings of the Magistri, just as about the three earlier things
Our Giles, in this distinction, first part, second question
Aegidius Romanos, I, d. 17, pars 1, q. 2 . shows. Concerning the other three things
Thomas of Strasbourg, in the same distinction, question one, in some article Thomas de Argentina, I, d. 17, q. 1, a. XX , see his responses and the arguments proving the caused habit of charity not being in its power.

To the second it is said that the antecedent is true concerning the constitutive, intrinsic, or informative form, but the Holy Spirit is an intrinsic form to the mind in this way because the Holy Spirit does not inhere in the mind. And I say further that through the Holy Spirit the mind is not intrinsically just In the third place I say that it is able to be conceded that there is not one well being of God and another for man, though the well being of God is in one way and the well being of man in another.

To the third, I say that the Apostle does not always speak in the same way, as is clear from the words of
Augustine in the third conclusion introducing the authority of Augustine who says
What is the Holy Spirit unless this charity of life made by the Holy Spirit? Augustinus, In epistolam Iohannis, Tractatus 6, 8 . I say in the first place that the authority in this form is against Dico primo quod auctoritas in forma est contra our Gregory and for thhe Master because
Augustine
say that
the Holy Spirit is nothing except the charity of life
Augustinus, In epistolam Iohannis, Tractatus 6, 8 . In the second place, I say that he does not say that the Holy Spirit is made or that charity is made absolutely, but that charity is made or that Holy Spirit is made in the mind because it begins to be charity in the mind and it began to be in the mind, just as God began to be in the world, nevertheless God never began to be. Therefore it makes a big difference to say that the Holy Spirit is made charity and to say that charity is made in you or that the Holy Spirit is made charity in you because the second is true and the first is false.

To the fourth, the antecedent is denied because the will is not distinguished from the essence of the soul, at least really. In the second place, I say that the consequence is not valid, even among Thomas of Strasbourg because has to concede that some accident is able to have many subjects, and nevertheless they will be one in number because according to him the immediate subject of the accidents is the quantity itself and the principal subject is substance and these are distinguished between themselves. Thus similarly, having posited that the will would be distinguished from the soul to this, the will is able to be the immediate subject of grace and the essence the principal subjec ot the soul, and thus it would be possible to be named by each name.
To the arguments in the opposition, it is clear from what has been said.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Iam nunc accedamus Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 1, n. 1 . The first conclusion: that the Holy Spirit , who is God and also intrinsically three persons from the Father and from the Son and from itself, proceeds temporally or is sent to the faithful and likewise is given.

Second conclusion: that the Holy Spirit is the love or charity by which we love God and our neighbor which charity is thus in us with the result that it makes us to love God, and our neighbor, then the Holy Spirit is said to be sent or to be given to us and the one who loves this
love by which he loves his neighbor loves God because this delight of God is the Holy Spirit, as one proves with the authority of Augustini.
Third conclusion: that the Holy Spirit is the love of the Father and the Son by which they love each other and us

The fourth conclusion: that God is called our hope and our patience, not because he is these, but because these are from God, nevertheless God is not called charity in this way because he is this charity itself, therefore it is able to be said that God or the Holy Spirit is the charity by which we love God, such that this ablative by which indicates the disposition of an efficient and formal cause, not perfecting and inhering, but exemplifying and elevating. The second part of this distinction follows.
